11:07 am
PM

Hold onto Your Hats - Explosion in Chinese Commodities Futures Brings Unprecedented Liquidity, Untested Volatility

PM

Chinese commodity futures markets have exploded in the past three weeks
Trading volumes in Chinese exchanges spiked exponentially, with SHFE rebar and DCE iron ore futures becoming the No.1 and No.3 most-traded contracts in the world, surpassing volumes of ICE Brent and NYMEX WTI contracts, which have been the most widely-traded and liquid contracts for three decades. The fact that iron ore, responsible for a small fraction of daily trade in oil and far less important for the global economy than oil, has attracted massive fund inflows in China is an indication of the excesses of Chinese futures exchanges and the dangers that wanton trading on Chinese exchanges may destabilize global markets. Trading in Chinese futures on some irrelevant commodities including bitumen, polypropylene, and PVC have also soared during the past weeks.

PM

The rapid development of Chinese futures markets since 2015 is likely due to three factors
1) domestic liquidity easing; 2) fund inflows from other asset classes, in particular from trading in stock index futures; and 3) rise of producer hedging activity in the face of falling commodity prices and a volatile RMB. Most recently, rising physical prices of bulk commodities has attracted investment interest across the industrial commodities space. A surge of agricultural product prices during the same period has generated more speculative long positions.

11:08 am
PM

But the recent surge of trading volumes has been mostly speculative, much more institutional than retail
Starting at the end of last year, short positions on iron ore, steel and base metals began to accumulate, accelerating in January as equity investors shifted from shorting equities during the big China sell-off and moved to short commodities as a way to profit from a slowing Chinese economy; and then they went suddenly long, apparently showing more confidence in the Chinese economy. But it was designed as well to lock in lower prices under the assumption that the RMB was weakening over the course of 2016, with higher priced dollars implying significantly higher RMB prices for commodities in China.

PM

Chinese futures markets to keep expanding over the next few years
This is partly thanks to the Chinese government’s desire to have commodities reflect a “MADE IN CHINA” aspect, including placing China at the center of the global commodities markets and having prices determined with RMB settlement. We believe potential opportunities should rise from the introduction of new contracts, growth of ETFs, and increasing producer hedging activities. We also identified risks to sustainable growth of Chinese futures markets, including physical settlement requirements in domestic futures markets, dangers in an expansion of commodity ETFs, uncertainties in futures market regulations, and limited opportunities for foreign participation. Furthermore, all of this growth poses multiple dangers to global commodity pricing stability given how less regulated and therefore less protective the Chinese regimes are for investors, who are perhaps the most speculative in the world.

PM

Just one more block

11:09 am
PM

Activity in Chinese commodity futures markets has exploded in the past two years. Key contracts in China's three major commodity futures markets, namely Shanghai Futures Exchange (SHFE), Dalian Commodity Exchange (DCE), and Zhengzhou Commodity Exchange (ZCE), have become some of the most widely-traded commodity futures contracts in the world. During the past three weeks, trading volumes in Chinese exchanges further spiked, with SHFE rebar and DCE iron ore futures becoming the No.1 and No.3 most-traded contracts around the world, and 11 of the top 20 traded futures contracts are on Chinese exchanges. On 21 April, a major contract of SHFE rebar "RB1610" reached daily trading volume of US$93 billion, exceeding the total volumes of the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges combined.

BE

Sellside incoming. JP Morgan downgrades.

BE

We are downgrading shares of TWTR from Overweight w/a $26 PT to Neutral w/a
$18 PT. Our TWTR bull case had been partly based on our view that TWTR’s real-time
platform was differentiated & that product improvements would drive increased
engagement & monetization over time. While we still remain bullish on the TWTR use
case, product changes have been slower & less impactful than we expected, &
TWTR faces increased competition from FB’s core Newsfeed, Instagram, &
Messenger, as well as from Snapchat. Importantly, we believe the low growth (no
growth in the US) in MAUs is weighing more on TWTR’s ad platform. MAUs remained
essentially flat in the US in 1Q for the 4th straight quarter, w/Int’l MAUs up a modest 4%
Y/Y. And during the last year, FXN ad revenue growth has decelerated from 78% in
1Q15 to 39% in 1Q16, & we now model it exiting 2016 in the teens. Brand advertiser
demand was weak in 1Q & TWTR continues to face challenges gaining greater share of
advertiser budgets, even w/solid traction in auto-play video. We recognize that many of
these factors are understood for Twitter & the company should see some improvements in
coming quarters. Users could benefit more in 2H16 from the Olympics, Euro 2016, US
election, & the NFL streaming deal. And ad improvements could come in video, DPAs, &
DoubleClick Bid Manager integration. However, we believe execution will be critical &
competition is narrowing the opportunity for growth in both users & ad dollars. Our
revenue & EBITDA estimates are coming down roughly 5-6% in 2016 & 13-14% in
2017. Our $18 PT is based on 10x 2017E EBITDA & equates to 25x 2017E non-GAAP
EPS.

BE

And MOST, which continues to sell.

11:21 am
BE

We remain cautious as TWTR's 1Q ad results and 2Q guidance were
3%/12% lower than expected due to softer branded advertiser
demand. We are reducing our 2017 revenue by 5% and non-GAAP
EBITDA by 2%. Our PT falls to $14.50 (from $16) and we reiterate
UW.
Impact on Thesis: TWTR's 1Q:16 results, 2Q:16 guidance and core (on
platform) ad revenue deceleration highlight our concerns around TWTR's
monetization limits as $531mn of 1Q ad revenue came in 3% below us and 2%
below the Street. Further, the mid-point of 2Q:16 revenue guidance ($590mn-
$610mn) was 2% below our previous estimate and 12% below the Street.
TWTR called out softer than expected branded advertiser demand, with
weakness picking up particularly in March and (thus far) into April. We find this
troubling given 1) Branded dollars are one of TWTR's largest buckets of ad
revenue and 2) The competition for social branded ad dollars from platforms
with higher user engagement and (in some cases) more scale continues rising
(Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, etc). In all, Twitter's core on-platform
(O&O) ad revenue decelerated to 23% YoY growth (from 30% in 4Q)
and given the guidance we now see this business slowing to 15% in 2Q
(See Exhibit 1). We see this steep deceleration continuing to pressure the
multiple investors are willing to pay for TWTR as we now see TWTR's core onplatform
ad revenue growing at a slower rate than GOOGL's Website business
and Facebook's ad business in 2016, despite TWTR being 1/30th and 1/12th
the size, respectively. Note too that for now we are assuming TWTR's ad
business re-accelerates in the back half (due to the NFL, presidential election
and the Rio Olympics)...which, if advertiser demand doesn't improve, still could
be aggressive.
On the positive side, 1Q:16 MAUs came in ~5mn (1.5%) ahead of us (driven by
international MAUs). 1Q non-GAAP EBITDA was 27% ($38mn) better than we
modeled as TWTR saw better than expected leverage in cost of revenue, R&D,
and G&A. That said, the company also said that Q1 "happened to be a quarter
where (they) did less investment than in Q2" and that "ultimately margins for
the full-year reflect the level of investment we plan on making with lumpiness
by quarter." We expect incremental infrastructure spend in 2Q:16 and that
some software development projects started during 1Q will result in higher
R&D and software spend going forward. As such, despite the 1Q EBITDA
margin upside, TWTR re-affirmed its full-year 2016 25%-27% non-GAAP
EBITDA margin guide.

BE

We remain cautious on TWTR and are lowering our 2017 non-GAAP EBITDA by 2%. We
were previously ~25% below Street 2017 non-GAAP EBITDA and will see
where expectations settle tomorrow. To become more positive, we look for
signs of TWTR improving its advertiser offerings (demographic targeting and
validation in addition to GRP and TRP targeting and reporting...and/or any
success in garnering incremental share of video ad budgets). We also look for
any further success in improving its core use case and value proposition.
Lowering 2017 Revenue by 5%...PT to $14.50, Maintain UW: As we adjust
our model, we are reducing our 2016/2017 revenue by 5%. Our 2016 non-
GAAP EBITDA estimate is roughly unchanged as the higher than expected
profitability in 1Q and 2Q guide (getting leverage in all opex lines) flows
through to offset the revenue reduction. That said, we lower our 2017 non-
GAAP EBITDA by 2% and our longer-term EBITDA and cash flow are adversely
impacted as our DCF-based PT falls to $14.50. In all, our new PT implies paying
11X 2017 non-GAAP EBITDA for a company set to grow its top-line 14% in
2017.

BE

Who can we quote here? Drexel Hamilton maybe.

BE

• Apple reported a soft 2Q:FY16 and offered up a cautious 3Q:FY16 outlook;
however, we believe the sales, profit and iPhone unit cycle will bottom in
3Q:FY16. We are reducing our estimates and adjusting our price target to
$185.00 from $200.00.
• Also, Apple expanded its capital return program from the $200 billion
through March 2017 to $250 billion through March 2018. This includes a
10% quarterly cash dividend increase to $0.57 from $0.52. We continue to
look forward to a new iPhone cycle with the iPhone 7 and new geographic
opportunities (e.g., India, Tier 3-5 cities in China).
• Apple reported Apple reported 2Q:FY16 sales of $50.56 billion (down 13%
YoY as reported and down 9% in constant currency) that missed our estimate
of $52.36 billion and the Street estimate of $51.98 billion, while pro forma
EPS of $1.90 fell short of our $1.99 projection and the Street (Street was at
$2.00).
• As the iPhone 6-Series nears the end of this two-year cycle and the macro
backdrop remains challenging, volatility in Apple's results is to be expected;
however, we believe the market is looking forward to the iPhone 7 in
September. Apple remained cautious around the macro environment and
thus plans to reduce channel inventory by over $2 billion in 3Q:FY16. That
said, our revised model now reflects a bottom in the operating profit cycle,
a trough in the sales cycle and a bottom in the iPhone unit cycle in 3Q:FY16.
• During 2Q:FY16, Apple reported iPhone unit sales of 51.19 million that beat
our estimate of 48.05 million. Apple highlighted a strong start to the iPhone
SE and India was again a standout market for the iPhone with total iPhone
sales growing 56% YoY.
• Given the late stages of this 6-Series cycle and growing macro volatility, it
is not surprising that Apple's 3Q:FY16 outlook is cautious. For 3Q:FY16,
Apple expects sales of $41-43 billion that is below the Street (Street is at
$47.35 billion) and lower than our estimate of $44.55 billion. We are cutting
our 3Q:FY16 revenue estimate to $42.05 billion from $44.55 billion and
decreasing our EPS projection to $1.37 from $1.60 (Street is at $1.75). For
FY:16, we are lowering our EPS projection to $8.06 from $8.54 and reducing
our FY:17 EPS projection to $9.19 from $10.22.

BE

11:31 am
BE

Macquarie incoming.

BE

 The Bottom Line – While the quarter wasn’t as bad as some feared, June quarter
guidance will spook the market. The issue remains iPhone sales. There were puts
and takes in the other businesses, but the main concern is that June guidance
implies iPhones units and ASP’s decelerating even further (we estimate 39mm
units). The U.S. and China, the two largest markets, are showing the most
weakness, down 10% and 26% respectively (though mainland China was down
less on an FX-adj basis). In our view, there are two simple explanations for the
iPhone weakness:1) Comp’ing iPhone 6 growth and 2)Lack of “must-have”
innovation
 The first issue is simply that there was massive pent up demand for larger
screens. This led to the mother of all upgrades when the iPhone 6 was released.
We don’t think this is anything structural and will be solved by time. However, the
second issue is a more significant concern. We believe that the lack of new “musthave”
innovative features will lengthen the upgrade cycle. If iPhone 7 doesn’t
surprise with meaningful new useful features, we worry that consumers won’t
upgrade. And unfortunately, nothing that we’ve seen about iPhone 7 thus far
strikes us as particularly innovative. Apple will be a show-me story until then (at
least on iPhone)
 Perhaps the most significant bright spot in the quarter was the area that we focus
on: Services (which include apps and Apple Music). Recognized Services
revenue was up 20% and the App Store was up 35% y/y. Installed base related
purchases hit almost $10b in the quarter, up 27%, a three point acceleration from
December. Apple Music now has 13mm paid subs. We believe that the Services
business accounted for 23% of gross profits in the quarter and will comprise 25%
of FY’17 gross profits. Notably, as we expected, the company itself is spending
more and more time talking about the Services business as a key driver of future
growth. Additionally, we felt that Tim Cook’s commentary suggested an Apple that
is more open to large acquisitions to help it innovate in current, and potentially,
new categories. We will not be surprised to see a more acquisitive AAPL in the
future.
 The bottom line is that AAPL needs new innovation either in its current categories
or in entirely new products (car?) in order to drive consumer and investor
excitement. There is value here, and based on the calendar, iPhone comps will
get easier by December. Additionally, Services are clearly receiving more
attention from the company and investors. We are reiterating our Buy and
lowering our target to $112

11:37 am
PM

Rocket's 'proven winner' GFG (Global Fashion Group) has raised €300 million in fresh capital in a new funding raise. It is clearly partner Kinnevik who has led this round (and marked a more realistic valuation). Kinnevik committed to invest up to €200m in this capital increase and Rocket expects to invest up to €85 million, including the conversion of an existing investment (of which no details are provided). Pre-funding has been provided by way of a EUR 50m shareholder loan during the first quarter, which perhaps suggests a cash crunch at GFG. But the key here is that the raise values GFG at €1bn post transactions. AT THE END OF MARCH GFG was valued at €3BN in Rocket's own LPV calculations. At the last count Rocket owned 22.5% of GFG and had €680m contribution from GFG for their own LPV calculation. So GFG's contribution was 11.5% of total Rocket LPV. We have no details yet of what Rocket's % ownership is now, but if it was unchanged this would take Rocket's own LPV down by €460 million.

So, in this regard, we note Kinnevik has marked to market its eCommerce companies NAV by -17% QoQ and total NAV by -13% QoQ in the Q1 release this morning. Rocket didn't reduce its own LPV calculations at the last report (March) given two weeks ago. The fair value comparisons of mutual investments are stark. With the update from Kinnevik this morning the differences in ascribed valuations are stark, see chart below:

PM

I will get the chart in a mo

PM

So, it also begs the question. What about the other LPV calculations in the Rocket portfolio? Surely the ability to raise at higher post money valuations has come to an end. Mutual funds have significantly marked down private valuations, there has been a slowing mega-round activity, scepticism of sky-high startup valuations and macro-economic concerns. This all weighed on the number of new VC backed companies entering the 'unicorn' club. In fact, this number had already dropped by almost 50% in Q4 from the Q2/Q3 highs in 2015, and the drop is precipitous in Q1 this this year, see chart below:

BE

We derive our new EPS estimates, c20% lower in
2016/17E and c10% lower thereafter, based on these trends and the new guidance
provided by management.
Our main conclusions are the following:
(i) Tesco’s ability to generate cash flow in the foreseeable future could be
more constrained than we thought before the results;
(ii) The results were of lower quality than it seemed at first glance;
(iii) The upcoming news flow is likely going to remain negative across the
industry and for Tesco in particular, we believe, as we expect the
discounters to react to Tesco’s Farm brands and Asda to sequentially
improve its performance;
(iv) We acknowledge that the improving UK LFL volume trend poses a risk
to our UW thesis but rather believe it is more likely set to fade in the
coming months as competition intensifies.

BE

BE

At c£740m, FCF generation in ‘15/16 was decent for this stage of the turnaround, we
believe. We note, however, that FCF benefited from the following tailwinds that are
unlikely to recur to the same extent in 2016/17E:
- Capex of c£1bn (well below depreciation of £1.3bn, down 45% from £2bn
in 2014/15 and £3bn in 2012/13);
- Working capital improvement of £350mn (inc £280mn inflow generated by
the discontinuation of Korea up to the point of disposal);
- No tax payment in the year (tax loss carry-forward following last year’s
losses in the UK);

BE

Actually, let me spin back up to page one.

BE

 FCF: Following a more prudent profitability outlook, higher capex guided,
smaller WC tailwinds & normalized taxes, we do not expect FCF to
improve in 2016/17E, projecting £716m FCF (4.5% FCF yield or 6% at our
150p PT).
 Profitability: We are of the view that some of the tailwinds benefiting
EBIT in 2015/16E are unlikely to recur to the same extent going forward
(e.g. GM expansion, stock losses reduction, shrinking fuel within the mix,
declining operating leases, extended asset lives etc; see Tables 3-7).
Surprisingly, operating costs (EBITDAR less implied gross profit) were up
c£200mn YoY to £11.4bn from £11.2bn despite £400mn of cost savings
delivered. We believe that Tesco’s high fixed cost base and increasing
variable costs, in combination with a reduced pace of cost savings
opportunity going forward could result in a muted margin expansion in the
UK of 30bp YoY to 1.5% in 2016/17E (sequence: 1.6% in 2H15/16 after
0.8% in 1H15/16 from losses in 2H14/15).
 B/S: We view Tesco’s progress in reducing indebtedness as impressive, but
the B/S remains stretched, at 4.6x LA (lease adjusted) ND/EBITDAR. This
remains a concern in the context of Tesco’s thin margins and the more
marked structural and cyclical headwinds within its core UK market.

BE

Standard Chartered reported 1Q16 results today which beat our expectations,
driven by a better cost, capital and impairment performance. However, we
think the share price performance today (+10% at close) is not justified by the
revenue outlook, and forecast returns in 2018. We have revenues in 2018 rising
13% from 1Q16 annualised levels but this is only enough to produce a 5% RoE
in 2018. The shares are trading at 0.7x 2015/16 TNAV. Revenues would either
need to be US$1bn higher to hit a 7% RoE, or impairments zero. Given the
current environment neither scenario seems likely and we downgrade our
recommendation to Sell, with a lowered TP of 454p.

The shares have travelled well into today’s numbers – up 19% in 3 weeks - yet on 0.6x 2015-18e tNAV, we still see reasonable further upside. Adj PBT of £902m is 3% ahead of us (£875m) and 7% ahead of consensus (£846m). As guided, this “underlying” measure includes negative, but transitory, volatility (-£374m) in Q1 from the ESHLA portfolio. In our view, the results reflect relative resilience, with notable outperformance vs peers in IB where revenues fell just 6% Q1/Q1. tNAV improved by 11p QoQ to 286p. BUY.

11:53 am
PM

The results appear uncharacteristically clean, with only one “notable item” – a negative £109m own credit move. There are no separately disclosed “below the line” conduct charges at all, and all restructuring charges (which were above the anticipated FY run-rate) are taken “above the line”.

Under Barclays’ new basis of disclosure, the performance of certain key divisions is somewhat obscured. Indeed, even the “pure” Investment Banking result is partially concealed. Yet, based on what is comparable, and as widely expected, IB actually boasts a revenue performance that compares favourably with virtually every peer. In aggregate, IB revenues are down by only £0.1bn (- 6%) Q1/Q1 to £1.9bn, with Credit (£0.3bn) up £0.1bn (+46%), Equities (£0.5bn) down £0.1bn (-13%), Macro (£0.6bn) down £0.1bn (-13%) and Banking fees (£0.5bn) down £0.1bn (-12%).

PM

Elsewhere, largely as expected, the revenue performance of the UK businesses appears relatively soft - down 2% across Personal Banking, Barclaycard Consumer UK, and Wealth, Entrepreneurs & Business Banking.

At a group level, the £0.1bn (+7%) “consensus beat” in u/l PBT is attributable to a £0.2bn (3%) revenue beat, and a £0.1bn (11%) impairment beat, offset by a £0.2bn (5%) “miss” on costs, due to front-loading of restructuring spend.

Barclays trades on 0.6x Q1 2016 tNAV of 286p. (An 11p QoQ rise in tNAV reflects retained earnings and reserve movements). Buy recommendation and 195p TP reaffirmed, with only the finer detail of our forecasts under review.

PM

The raft of data due just hours before the BoJ releases its April decision is likely to
paint a fairly bleak picture, with consumption and inflation both losing steam.

PM

As is often the case, a wave of key economic data (inflation, labour market and
consumption) is released just a few hours before the BoJ’s announcement, making it
particularly market relevant. The most important release, CPI, is likely to show that the
headline rate ticked lower again to 0.1% YoY, based on Tokyo’s data released with a
one-month lead. As ever though, the BoJ’s focus will be their own measure of core CPI
(excl. fresh food and energy), which we expect to come in at or below last month’s
reading of 1.1%. As the lagged effect of previous JPY depreciation starts to filter out of
the data, this CPI measure should start to trend downwards throughout this year; the
latest FX appreciation will only accelerate this process.

11:57 am
PM

On the surface, the labour market data is one economic bright spot, with the
unemployment rate likely to remain at its post-1997 low of 3.3%. Although encouraging,
virtually all of the gains have come from part-time employment (up 9.4% from 2010) and
full-time jobs have been slowly scaled back. Compare this to the US, where full-time jobs
have made up the bulk of employment growth (part-time jobs have remained broadly
constant). Thus, unlike in the US, tighter labour market conditions in Japan are unlikely to
exert significant upward pressure on wages. Indeed, future wage growth is likely to be
highly sensitive to exchange rate movements (for more, see page 2 of our BoJ Preview).
This has important implications for consumption. The recent hit to equity markets,
combined with disappointing spring wage negotiations, may adversely affect spending
this year. March’s Household Spending survey, which is relevant for the GDP
calculations, is likely to have increased, which together with earlier readings, would put

PM

1Q consumption at around 0.4% QoQ. This may help the economy to narrowly avoid a
dip, although wouldn’t fully offset the weather-induced fall in consumer spending during
4Q. Indeed, in year-on-year terms, household expenditure is still down by around 4%.
Thus, when taken together, this data will emphasise the uncertainty surrounding the
economic outlook. With markets increasingly pricing-in further BoJ stimulus, we expect an
increase in purchases of risk assets and a move to negative rates on the Loan Support
Programme this week. F

Doug Creutz and Cowan writes ......

BE

This M&A Speculation Seems About Six Years Too Late

12:00 pm
BE

We believe that DWA has attempted to find buyers in the past on several occasions,
unsuccessfully. Given the company's continued uneven box office performance and
marginal profitability, we have a hard time believing any deal will happen, particularly
given the lack of strategic logic for Comcast.
First of all, Comcast already owns what has become a significantly more successful
film animation unit, Illumination Entertainment, which has had major success with the
Despicable Me/Minions franchise. Chasing another animation film studio which at this
point lacks compelling IP would not make a lot of sense, in our view.
While top-line growth in the Dreamworks TV segment is coming along a little better
than we expected, we note that DWA has become increasingly dependent on Netflix
buying their content. We would say that Comcast probably views Netflix as more of a
threat than a desirable business partner.
While AwesomenessTV has been a nice incremental revenue stream for DWA
with solid growth/margin characteristics, DWA now only owns half the asset, and
Comcast's direct competitor Verizon recently bought a 24.5% minority stake, which we
think would not align well with Comcast's interests.
DWA shares have risen recently in large part because of new deals announced
with Netflix and Verizon; we suspect those wells have now been fully tapped. We
believe that based on the recent performance of Kung Fu Panda 3, current consensus
estimates for 2016 are probably too high. We also have significant concerns about
the likely performances of DWA’s next two films, Trolls (November 2016) and The
Boss Baby (March 2017), particularly the former which is opening directly against
Disney/Marvel's Dr. Strange. We suspect this would all be apparent to Comcast as
well, which would seem to suggest that even if they are interested, waiting might be a
more prudent course of action.
In total, we view the likelihood of a takeout of DWA by Comcast at a premium to
current prices as being very low.
